title: Fiberglass Batt vs Dense-Pack Cellulose Wall Insulation

LIS.summary: Cellulose generally has lower embodied impact per unit of thermal performance, driven by recycled content and low-temperature processing.
LIS.relative_position: cellulose favored when both are installed well

CPI.summary: Similar or slightly higher upfront cost for cellulose, with better lifecycle performance when installation quality is high.

sections.overview: This comparison looks at two cavity insulation options for framed walls: standard fiberglass batts and dense-pack cellulose. Both can achieve similar R-values, but they differ in embodied impact, installation quality, and long-term behavior.

why_it_scores_this_way.LIS: Fiberglass batts rely on high-temperature melting and spinning processes, plus binders and facings, while dense-pack cellulose uses recycled paper with lower-energy processing. Over the lifecycle, cellulose often carries lower embodied impact per unit of thermal resistance when installed correctly.
why_it_scores_this_way.RIS: Dense-pack cellulose scores higher on regenerative performance due to recycled feedstock, biogenic carbon storage, and more circular end-of-life options. Fiberglass remains inert and non-combustible but is less circular and more dependent on petrochemical components.

tradeoffs: Cellulose requires skilled installers and blowing equipment
Fiberglass batts are more vulnerable to gaps and compression
Cellulose can buffer some moisture but must be able to dry
Fiberglass can hide condensation against cold sheathing
Fiberglass is often the lowest upfront cost and most widely stocked

choose_this_when: Choose dense-pack cellulose when recycled content and carbon storage are priorities
Choose dense-pack cellulose when you have access to experienced installers
Choose dense-pack cellulose when sound control and draft reduction matter
Choose dense-pack cellulose when targeting higher RIS tiers
choose_alternative_when: Choose fiberglass batts when lowest upfront cost dominates the decision
Choose fiberglass batts when crews are already standardized on batt installation
Choose fiberglass batts when framing is regular and simple to insulate
Choose fiberglass batts when cellulose supply or installers are limited

alternatives: Wood-fiber batts or boards in high-performance assemblies
Hybrid assemblies combining cellulose with exterior continuous insulation
sections.takeaway: On paper, fiberglass batts and dense-pack cellulose can look similar in R-value. In practice, cellulose tends to offer lower embodied impact, better circularity, and tighter real-world performance when installed well, while fiberglass favors cost and familiarity.
